para.paratext: Courts may take judicial notice of records and proceedings in the same case in the same court,[1] but not of another case in the same court or of proceedings in other courts.[2] However, a court will take judicial notice of the record of an earlier appearance of the same case in that court,[3] but it may not take judicial notice of matters that are the subject of proof in a case, and may refuse to take judicial notice of findings of fact and conclusions of law in previous orders where the court has determined that those issues are for a jury to decide.[4] A trial court cannot take judicial notice of pleadings or orders from other courts of the state because such issues are a matter of proof that cannot be judicially noticed. Certified copies of such pleadings have to be tendered and received as evidence.[5] The court will not take judicial notice of a former suit in the same court between the same parties.[6] In addition, the appellate court will not take judicial notice of local practice rules.[7]

Petkas v. Grizzard[8] involved a question of whether a trial court could take judicial notice of the record in a prior suit in the same court in order to determine if the action fell within the provisions of the renewal statute. The Georgia Supreme Court held that the trial court had properly taken notice of the pleadings and record of the former case and stated, “In deciding that a trial court is authorized to take judicial notice of records in the same court, we do not hold that a judge is required to do so. The court may require the parties to present evidence on the issue.”

In a termination of parental rights case, the Georgia Court of Appeals approved taking judicial notice of previous deprivation orders involving a father confined to a pretrial detention center in Florida.[9]

In Fitzpatrick v. Harrison,[10] the Georgia Court of Appeals found that the trial court erred by considering pleadings from the underlying civil action in a professional malpractice case against an attorney stating that “the trial court could not properly make factual findings based upon evidence contained in those pleadings ‘because such issues are a matter of proof that cannot be judicially noticed.’” The trial court had stated that it was going to take judicial notice of the “physical pleadings” from the divorce action but “not of any legal conclusion contained therein.”[11] The Georgia Supreme Court held that a trial court must announce its intention to take judicial notice of a fact on the record and afford the parties an opportunity to speak regarding whether it should take judicial notice.[12]

Thus, in Cantrell v. State,[13] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that a trial court could not properly take judicial notice of the defendant's waiver of his Fourth Amendment rights in a bond order entered in a prior case without first announcing its intention to do so on the record and affording defendant and state an opportunity to be heard on the issue. Otherwise, the court deprives the accused of an opportunity to challenge whether the trial court has properly taken judicial notice of the fact at issue.

The Court of Appeals also examined taking judicial notice of the court's file in a case where the clerk's original file was allegedly missing for quite some time. The Court of Appeals held that, where a motion to set aside a judgment was pending, the trial court could not take judicial notice of items not within the court's file at the time a hearing on the merits of the motion was held. The court further explained that O.C.G.A §§ 24-11-1 et seq. sets out the correct procedure to follow where records are missing from the clerk's official file.[14]
